greeting: Greetings from The On-Line Encyclopedia of Integer Sequences! http://oeis.org/

results.name: If n is prime, set a(n) = 1. Otherwise, start with the multiset of prime factors of n, and given a multiset take the multiset of its multiplicities. Repeating this until a multiset of size 1 is reached, set a(n) to the unique element of this multiset.
comment: a(n) depends only on prime signature of n (cf. A025487). - _Antti Karttunen_, Nov 08 2018
link: Antti Karttunen, Table of n, a(n) for n = 1..16384
Antti Karttunen, Data supplement: n, a(n) computed for n = 1..100000
Index entries for sequences computed from exponents in factorization of n
formula: a(p^n) = n where p is any prime number.
a(product of n distinct primes) = n.
a(1) = 0; and for n > 1, if n = prime^k, a(n) = k, otherwise, if n is squarefree [i.e., A001221(n) = A001222(n)], a(n) = A001221(n), otherwise a(n) = a(A181819(n)). - _Antti Karttunen_, Nov 08 2018
example: Starting with the multiset of prime factors of 2520 we have {2,2,2,3,3,5,7} -> {1,1,2,3} -> {1,1,2} -> {1,2} -> {1,1} -> {2}, so a(2520) = 2.
program: A304465(n) = if(1==n,0,my(t=isprimepower(n)); if(t,t, t=omega(n); if(bigomega(n)==t),t,A304465(A181819(n)))); \\ _Antti Karttunen_, Nov 08 2018
results.author: _Gus Wiseman_, May 13 2018
